ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: It is a dense course, and definitely would not recommend taking it without background in Archaeology, but so beneficial if you have.

I would recommend Archaeological Theory if you are really interested in Archaeology (or a major in which case it is a requirement). It is pretty heavily focused on theory and philosophy, so I would not recommend the course if that does not appeal to you.

Don't take it if you're not a major...but if you are it's one of those classes where you look back and realized you learned a lot more than you thought at the time. No exams or papers but a lot of reading summaries and class presentations.

I would certainly recommend this class to anyone else at all interested in archaeology, both for the theoretical foundations it provides (a great deal of which I didn't even realized existed as issues prior to this class) and even just to get a feel for the department (there's a lot of graduate students and it's taught by archaeology's awesome DUS Professor McIntosh). Other than that the general grounding in theory and philosophy of social science that it provides is still very valuable, but I imagine other students might want to find another class also giving them such a background but more tailored to their own interests.
